awd_titl_txt: SpecEES: Energy-efficient Spectrum and Infrastructure Co-use for Sensing and Communications in Dense Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will develop new energy-efficient techniques to co-use wireless spectrum for both communications and sensing. The setting considered will be that of emerging cellular networks consisting of a dense deployment of base-stations (wireless infrastructure on cell towers) providing overlapping wireless coverage. By enabling co-use of spectrum, this research will result in both better connectivity and improved data rates to users, and improved sensing through radar technologies for locating and tracking mobile users. These technologies will thus enable new smart city services and applications. On the educational front, the project will lead to development of new educational materials. Outreach activities to middle and high school students will occur through widely-accessible lecture series.  The proposed activities will pay special attention to promoting diversity and nurturing student talent. Finally, the results will be shared with industry through the industrial affiliates program of the Wireless Networking and Communications Group (WNCG) at The University of Texas at Austin. 

The proposed research is geared at developing a new class of energy efficient cross-layer resource allocation algorithms for joint management of base-station and spectrum resources in dense wireless networks.  At the same time, mathematical models and tools based on stochastic geometry will be introduced enabling one to characterize and optimize energy-performance for dense deployments. The intellectual merit can be summarized along four thrusts: (a) Infrastructure and spectrum co-use for communications and radar/sensing, where the focus will be on algorithms for handling interference from a mixture of communications and radar waveforms; (b) Stochastic geometry models and tools for characterizing heterogeneous spectrum use over space, where Central Limit Theorems over space will be developed to characterize SINR and radar distortion performance; (c) Algorithms for mode switching and base-station activation, where load-dependent algorithms for network management will be developed that are cognizant of hysteresis costs associated with changing modes and activation states of base-stations; and (d) Managing user dynamics through directed association to reduce the frequency of change in the network, which will result in improved convergence behavior of management algorithms at various spatial scales.

por.por_cntn:
This proposal focused on efficient spectrum and energy usage in the face of densification. The proposal focused on three broad themes:

1. Resource co-use: How can we efficiently co-use spectrum resources for various tasks, including sensing (e.g through radar) and communications?

2. Resource switching: How should we deal with switching between various operational modes of the base-station?

3. Resource coupling: In this environment, the nature of wireless transmissions couples resource allocation strategies. How can we efficiently coordinate such strategies?

Our research focused on technical problems that arise due to these broad challenges, as detailed below. Along each of these directions, we developed algorithms and the associated performance analysis to evaluate the benefits of our approach. Some of the highlights from our work are listed below. Along the theme of co-use, we developed network slicing abstractions and how to map these to physical resources for multi-tenant resource slicing to enable resource sharing across heterogeneous clients. To address switching of resources, we developed new algorithms for managing activation state of base-stations to control energy usage, while ensuring that user performance does not suffer. Addressing both coupled systems and co-use, we analyzed a cellular deployment of radar sensing base stations. Such infrastructure may be co-deployed with a cellular communication infrastructure. Some of the outcomes along this thread included a characterization of the detection probability of blockage sensing by radars deployed on towers in cellular networks. Further, to ease the analysis of coupled wireless environments, we modeled radar (sensing) and blockage locations using stochastic geometry, and derive the detection probability as a function of the system parameters, chiefly the radar and blockage densities. The work gave insight into the ability of radars at base stations to detect blockages as a function of both the blockage and radar densities.

Through this project, we provided mentorship and training to graduate students that helped them grow their expertise spanning across several technical boundaries, including hardware prototyping and algorithm design, and sensing and communications in the millimeter wave band. Addressing technology transfer, we discussed our findings with industry partners through the Wireless Networking and Communications Group industrial affiliate program at UT Austin (sharing ideas through posters, talks and group meetings).
